Award.AwardTitle: Risk, Variability and Decision-making in Whole-Body Movements

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most daily movements involve some form of decision making under risk. For example, people do not reach as far on an elevated platform compared to level ground. Indeed, there are many behavioral examples of such risk-sensitive movement control even when the dynamics remain the same. Despite these widely observed risk-sensitive phenomena, there have been no quantitative descriptions of the underlying movement decision processes. This project aims to fill this gap, and develop dynamical models to identify the subjective costs and rationales underlying whole-body movement under risk. Movements will be analyzed under the framework of statistical decision-making under conditions of risk. Subjects will perform whole-body movements in conditions of varying postural threat. The behavioral changes observed between these conditions, in conjunction with model predictions, will be used to infer the subjective risk-sensitivity associated with the increased postural threat. This approach will inform the analysis of risk-, variability- and age-related changes in functional performance, and provide insights about the mechanisms underlying risk-seeking and risk-averse behavior in a variety of movements.


This project is expected to advance knowledge and understanding in the general area of neuromuscular dynamics and decision-making under risk; that is, how our central nervous system weighs risks and rewards when moving our bodies. Although great achievements in neuroscience have helped us to understand how our nervous system controls our movements, relatively little is known about how our sense of risk, especially as we age, influences these movements. An understanding of the effect of risk and variability on balance and falls can direct future research targeting injury prevention, identification of those at risk for falls, and the design of interventions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most daily movements involve some form of decision making. However, the mechanisms underlying the choice to walk slowly or quickly, to reach up on one’s toes into the cupboard or to use a stool are poorly understood. For example, people do not reach as far on an elevated platform compared to level ground. Indeed, there are many behavioral examples of risk-sensitive movement control even when the dynamics remain the same. Despite these widely observed risk-sensitive phenomena, there have been no quantitative descriptions of the underlying movement decision processes. Purely biomechanical studies of whole-body reaching and stepping are unable to distinguish between appropriate and inappropriate decision making because they overlook the role of sensorimotor variability, and do not quantify risk. Computational models of goal-directed arm movements incorporate variability, but they have yet to consider the inherent instability and risk of a fall characteristic of whole-body movements. As a result, there is no quantitative method for evaluating appropriate and inappropriate risk valuation. This project sought to fill this gap, and develop models to identify the subjective costs and rationales underlying both whole-body and reaching movements under risk.

In a series of studies we measured whole body movements and reaching movements in both young and older adults, and used an optimal control framework to understand the subjective costs underlying their movement decisions. We found that the learning of whole body movements are significantly affected by stability limits. People adapt less and more slowly in the presence of instability. Our results also show that threat plays an important role in out perception of probability. In threatening situations, we are more cautious which can be explained by a distortion in our estimates of variability. Specifically, people overestimate their movement variability in high threat situations, which leads to more cautious movement decisions. We found that while older adults appear to learn less than younger adults, this apparent reduction in learning can be explained by differences in subjective costs. Older adults care more about effort than error, and thus learn movements differently than younger adults. This does not necessarily mean that they are unable to learn as well as younger adults. Our results highlight the importance of considering the role of subjective costs when interpreting the learning of novel movement strategies. Finally, we also investigated the interaction between time and effort cost. We found that contrary to current thinking, time does play a role in our decisions to invest a given amount of effort. For a fixed amount of effort, people prefer to invest that effort earlier, rather than later. In other words, we find that people are effort precrastinators and would prefer to get the costly movement out of the way, rather than put it off. Similar results have also been observed in pain perception. Our effort-related findings have important implications in the design of programs that incentivize effort and physical activity.

Taken together, our findings highlight the importance of taking into account subjective costs in our analsyis of movement decisions. We demonstrate this in a range of movements (arm and whole-body), populations (young and older adults), and movement costs (stability and effort). We hope that these findings shed new light on the both the different costs influencing our movement decisions as well as their subjective nature.
